text: And Isaac digged again the wells of water, which they had digged in the days of Abraham his father; for the Philistines had stopped them after the death of Abraham: and he called their names after the names by which his father had called them.
text_kjv: And Isaac digged again the wells of water, which they had digged in the days of Abraham his father; for the Philistines had stopped them after the death of Abraham: and he called their names after the names by which his father had called them.
text_niv: Isaac reopened the wells that had been dug in the time of his father Abraham, which the Philistines had stopped up after Abraham died, and he gave them the same names his father had given them.
text_esv: And Isaac dug again the wells of water that had been dug in the days of Abraham his father, which the Philistines had stopped after the death of Abraham. And he gave them the names that his father had given them.
text_nlt: He reopened the wells his father had dug, which the Philistines had filled in after Abraham’s death. Isaac also restored the names Abraham had given them.
text_msg: Isaac dug again the wells which were dug in the days of his father Abraham but had been clogged up by the Philistines after Abraham's death. And he renamed them, using the original names his father had given them.
text_nasb: Then Isaac dug again the wells of water which had been dug in the days of his father Abraham, for the Philistines had stopped them up after the death of Abraham; and he gave them the same names which his father had given them.
context: Genesis 26:18 unfolds against the backdrop of a nomadic pastoral society where water was not merely a convenience, but a life-or-death necessity. The Philistines, a seafaring people who had settled along the coastal plains of Canaan, posed a constant threat to the indigenous populations, including Abraham and later, Isaac. Well digging was a laborious and resource-intensive endeavor. Ownership of wells represented control over vital resources and, by extension, control over the land itself. Abraham, Isaac's father, had previously dug wells in the region of Gerar, establishing a claim to the land and securing a vital resource for his family and livestock. However, after Abraham's death, the Philistines, perhaps motivated by a desire to consolidate their power and limit the growth of Isaac's clan, deliberately stopped up these wells, filling them with earth and debris. This action was a direct challenge to Isaac's claim to the land and a hostile act designed to weaken his position. Isaac's act of re-digging the wells was therefore not merely a practical matter of obtaining water, but a symbolic act of reclaiming his inheritance, reasserting his rights, and continuing the legacy of his father. The act of renaming the wells after their original names further emphasizes the importance of remembering and honoring the past, and of laying claim to the promises made to Abraham. This context highlights the socio-political tensions of the time and provides insight into the strategic importance of water resources in shaping relationships and boundaries.
meaning: Theologically, Genesis 26:18 speaks to the themes of inheritance, promise, and faithfulness in the face of adversity. Isaac's act of re-digging the wells represents his commitment to upholding the covenant God made with Abraham. The wells symbolize not only physical sustenance but also the spiritual blessings and promises associated with the land. By re-digging and renaming them, Isaac demonstrates his faith that God's promises to Abraham are still valid and applicable to him. The Philistines' actions of stopping the wells represent opposition to God's plan and an attempt to thwart the fulfillment of His promises. Their actions mirror the forces of evil that constantly seek to undermine God's work in the world. Isaac's perseverance in the face of this opposition is a testament to his trust in God's provision and protection. The act of naming the wells after Abraham's names highlights the importance of remembering and honoring God's faithfulness in the past. It serves as a reminder that God's promises are not contingent upon circumstances but are rooted in His unchanging character. Isaac's actions also reflect a model of stewardship and responsibility. He recognizes the importance of preserving and utilizing the resources God has provided, not only for his own benefit but also for the benefit of future generations. This verse emphasizes the continuity of God's covenant and the importance of maintaining a connection to the past while moving forward in faith.
application: In today's world, Genesis 26:18 offers several practical applications. Firstly, it encourages us to reclaim and restore what has been lost or damaged. This could refer to broken relationships, neglected talents, or abandoned dreams. Just as Isaac re-dug the wells, we should be willing to put in the effort to rebuild and revitalize what has been left in disrepair. Secondly, the verse highlights the importance of perseverance in the face of opposition. Like Isaac, we will inevitably encounter obstacles and challenges that seek to hinder our progress and undermine our faith. We must not be discouraged by these setbacks but instead, remain steadfast in our commitment to God's calling and purpose for our lives. Thirdly, the act of renaming the wells serves as a reminder to honor our heritage and learn from the past. We should remember the lessons of those who have gone before us and draw strength from their examples of faith and resilience. This also calls us to actively remember God's faithfulness in our own lives and to pass down these stories of His provision and guidance to future generations. Fourthly, this verse encourages us to be good stewards of the resources God has entrusted to us. This includes not only material possessions but also our time, talents, and relationships. We should use these resources wisely and responsibly, seeking to make a positive impact on the world around us. Finally, Isaac's actions demonstrate the importance of standing up for what is right, even when it is difficult or unpopular. We should not be afraid to challenge injustice and to advocate for those who are marginalized or oppressed. Just as Isaac reasserted his claim to the wells, we should be willing to speak out against evil and to defend the truth.
prayer: Heavenly Father, thank you for the example of Isaac, who persevered in the face of adversity and faithfully reclaimed what was rightfully his. Lord, help us to have the same courage and determination to re-dig the wells in our own lives – to restore what has been broken, to revive what has been neglected, and to reclaim what has been lost. Grant us the wisdom to learn from the past, the strength to overcome obstacles, and the faith to trust in your provision. Help us to be good stewards of the resources you have entrusted to us and to use them for your glory. Remind us of your faithfulness and steadfast love, and empower us to be a beacon of hope in a world that desperately needs your light. In Jesus' name, Amen.

faqs.answer: The Philistines likely stopped up Abraham's wells out of jealousy and a desire to limit Isaac's power and expansion in their territory. Water was a vital resource, and controlling it meant controlling the land and its people. It was a hostile act meant to weaken Isaac's position.

faqs.answer: Naming the wells after Abraham was an act of honoring his father's legacy and reaffirming Isaac's connection to the covenant God made with Abraham. It served as a reminder of God's faithfulness and the promises passed down through generations.

faqs.answer: We learn the importance of perseverance, faith, and resilience in the face of opposition. Isaac's actions demonstrate that we should not be discouraged by setbacks but instead, remain committed to God's purpose and trust in His provision and protection.
